story: Can new parents afford to take parental leave?
description: Between the cost of childcare, transportation etc. can new parents afford to go back to work after they have a new child? Worded another way, how much do new parents need to make per hour (per state) to make the return to work financially "worth it"?
Examining the geographic locations people sing about most frequently

story: "Who shapes the English language?" but with quotes

description: Inspired by this paper.
Inspired by this Twitter thread: https://twitter.com/hormiga/status/913092766325817344 how many internship postings are either unpaid or require the applicant to pay?
Separating talking points from statistics when it comes to gun violence and exploring its impact in the US visually.
An homage to the great children's poet, create a visual poem remix using markov chains (eg. Lil’ Silverstein - Where Tha Carter Ends). In the style of his books.
Look at Twitter (?) to find all the things that people consider to be adulting?
Using geographic or geological data to create an actual album / soundtrack to America.
Looking at activities throughout time and how they've changed (eg. going to the movies). Presented through a hybrid of data and documentary.
A story about viral stories. It unlocks more content as certain viral milestones are hit.
Weddings in the US have a lot of traditions. Some are cultural, some are religious. But how many people actually stick to them, and how long have those traditions been around?
An interactive explainer about recall ability / working memory.
Prisonner's dilemna birthday paradox style.
Do athletes have a sharp or slow decline as they get older? Does it vary across sport?
Seattle became the first major US city to completely ban plastic straws. They were largely replaced with "compostable" straws, but how much of an environmental impact will the ban make?

Growing up this is what my mom would always say whenever state rankings came out for anything. Tennessee was always near the bottom, but we could always count on Mississippi to be worse. When you look at a state choropleth map, chances are the South stands out for all the wrong reasons. Some southerners like to gripe that it’s because the region wasn’t given a fair chance after the Civil War and during Reconstruction. And there have been a lot of studies about how the south is decades behind the rest of the country. Small multiple maps that rank the states (plus DC) from 1-51 in a bunch of different categories (need to think about how to choose categories). Aggregate rankings of states from those categories. Can I say the South is X years behind in X category? Slope charts showing the change over time by metric - is the South catching up?

I’ve always been fascinated my colors and the psychology behind them. This would take a nerd topic like color temperature and attempt to explain it using social media photos. Thinking this would be in a similar style to the Waveforms explainer, possibly shifting the color temperature of the page as you scroll. Then it would maybe pull in some info about how we encounter color temperatures in our photos now. Doesn’t look like I’d be able to do it with Instagram since they shut down their public API, but Flickr might work.

story: Ideal amount of time for comebacks
description: How much time has passed between when an original movie/tv show aired and its sequel/prequel/remake? What's the ideal amount of time between these two things (i.e., when do you hit "peak nostalgia"?)
Examining spending power over the years throughout North America.

story: What are the smartest people in the room most interested in?

description: The history, facts, figures, major players, etc., of the enornmous topic in one interactive timeline.

story: Quantity of media coming at us
description: Visualizing the amount of emails, headlines, and social media posts that target people daily.

story: What words define our social platforms

description: Based on the Reply All - Alex Jones episode. Do subscribers go up/down after a huge apology video?

I’ve seen countless headlines proclaiming “Millennials have killed X” or “Millennials are the death of Y.” That gives you a single item, but is there a larger pattern to what we have supposedly killed? Use headlines from NYTimes API for data through time or Google News for more recent data only. Find out the types of things Millennials have killed. Do other generations kill the same types of things?

story: NOW That’s What I Call Music
description: This year is the 20th anniversary and there have been 67 US albums since 1998. The songs included were the most “now” songs when each edition was released, but which album remains the most “now” now? Limit it to just albums released in 2008 or earlier to give a good gap between then and now (that gives us 29). Take the track list from each album and use the Spotify API to get the current popularity of a track. Maybe even use EchoNest points to find the NOW album that sounds most similar to today’s hits.

Kobe Bryant and Diana Taurasi are undoubtedly some of the best to ever play the game of basketball — they even share similar nicknames. This would be a love letter comparing their careers and marking the end of an era. Kobe’s already retired and Taurasi isn’t far out. Grab their seasonal data from Basketball Reference and see where it takes me.
Take a debated speech and annotate it. Or commission two people to have a debate and annotate.
Ask people if they know things. Then look at generational gaps.

story: What are the most re-read books?
description: Using goodreads API

More of a personal curiosity project, but there is a decently large cult fandom who would be into this. ShowTime plans to launch the reboot of the L Word by the end of the year, which is a HUGE cultural touchstone for just about every queer woman my age (admittedly, Sarah hasn’t seen it). One of the most meme-able things from the show was “the chart,” a hand drawn network diagram of who was dating who. The chart even turned into a social networking site called ourchart.com. The idea would be to rewatch every episode and plot the connections. I have a good friend, Alissa Scheller, who does data viz at Pew who wants in on this project. I’m thinking it would be similar to the LA Times’ Sex in the City dating table with some small networks or some other combination of the two approaches. One of the main characters, Shane, was a legendary womanizer, so it could rate the characters on how “Shane” they are.

story: The decline of banana in recipes
description: Apparently bananas were forced upon us by big banana industry. Are people still using recipes with bananas?

How has the genre of acts that perform at the mother church of country music changed over time. Are there any other venues so closely associated with a particular type of music that would be good to look at too?
Least viewed wiki pages as a passive experience, kind of like astronaut.io.
